end.title: My Survival as an Aboriginal
end.credit_line: Courtesy the Coffey family and Martha Ansara / the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia / Ballad Films
end.brief_description: Essie Coffey OAM was a Murawarri activist, advocate and filmmaker concerned about the influence of white culture and education on Indigenous children. As seen in her groundbreaking documentary, My Survival as an Aboriginal (1978), she taught culture to her community.

constellations_other.name: Jedda: Uneven ground, the road to on-screen diversity
constellations_other.description: Jedda was the first fully funded Australian feature to be shot on colour film. It was also the first Australian film with Aboriginal actors in lead roles, however, it reflects a deeply problematic time in Australian history.

constellations_other.name: Connecting through film
constellations_other.description: Film acts like a time capsule to our collective past. Capturing our most treasured moments with family has never been more accessible, with technology right at our fingers.

links.description: Murawarri activist and filmmaker Essie Coffey was one of the first Indigenous people to document the blak experience on film. Through My Survival as an Aboriginal she exposed how First Peoples were marginalised in all aspects of their lives, from school to wider society.

start.title: First Australians
start.brief_description: First Australians is a historical documentary series produced by Blackfella Films over the course of six years, and first aired in October 2008.

constellations_other.name: Rachel Perkins
constellations_other.description: The moving image has helped tell First Peoples stories through documentary, films and TV shows, with acclaimed director, producer and screenwriter Rachel Perkins contributing significantly to these stories.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

end.title: Forced into images
end.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour, silent
end.brief_description: In Destiny Deacon’s photographic series Forced into Images (a title taken from a poem by Alice Walker), a dramatic narrative unfolds that follows a girl’s troubled life from birth to womanhood. Deacon’s work often explores cultural stereotyping, domestic violence and the status of Indigenous women.

links.description: Destiny Deacon’s artwork Forced into Images is a Super 8 film featuring the artist’s young niece and nephew donning an array of masks with various adult faces. The work reflects the disconnect between Aboriginal identity, representation and societal expectation.

links.description: Teaming up again for Total Control, Rachel Perkins and Deborah Mailman create a powerful political drama centred around the character of an Indigenous senator. The series engages with issues of Aboriginal deaths in custody, land rights and women in politics.
